abstract.p: Jim Fuller letter agrees with Bill Friskics-Warren's premise in July 30 article on need for more mature approach to country music; lauds singer-songwriter Kathy Mattea (S)

block.p: I could not agree more with Bill Friskics-Warren's premise in his article about the need for a more mature approach to country music [''Country Gets Back to an Old Standard: Music for Grown-ups,'' July 30]. Mr. Friskics-Warren failed, however, to mention the premiere example of an artist who takes the thoughtful and introspective road: Kathy Mattea.

I could not agree more with Bill Friskics-Warren's premise in his article about the need for a more mature approach to country music [''Country Gets Back to an Old Standard: Music for Grown-ups,'' July 30]. Mr. Friskics-Warren failed, however, to mention the premiere example of an artist who takes the thoughtful and introspective road: Kathy Mattea.

In her recently released ''Innocent Years,'' Ms. Mattea, who co-wrote two of the CD's best tracks, puts forth a remarkable effort. If only country radio could wake up and make the more thoughtful artists the rule, and not the exception, they would indeed lure back the ''substance-starved'' listeners.
